msContents.summary: A modern paper manuscript of the Divyāvadāna, "Glorious Deeds", a collection of Buddhist tales very popular in Mediaeval and Early Modern Nepal. In the final stage of its redaction, this anonymous compilation consisted of 38 avadānas. It has been edited by E.B. Cowell and R.A. Neil in 1884, mainly on the basis of modern Nepalese paper manuscripts. However, many scholars have stressed the heterogeneous character of the stories included in the Divyāvadāna: for instance, 21 stories have a more or less literal parallel in the Mūlasarvāstivādavinaya (see Panglung 1981: XV), while the 38th tale in Cowell and Neil's edition, the Maitrakanyakāvadāna, is now attributed to Gopadatta (see Hahn: 1992, passim and Klaus 1983: 5 ff.). In the edition, the present manuscript has been given the siglum A: Add.865 in the Univ. Library; [...] dated 1873. Fairly written in the ordinary Nepalese character, but not very correct. (Cowell and Neil 1884: vi).

msItem.title: Divyāvadāna
msItem.incipit: [1v1] buddho bhagavāñ śrāvastyāṃ viharati sma jetavane 'nāthapiṇḍadasyārāme 'apasmārāntake vāsavagrāme balaseno nāma gṛhapatiḥ prativasa[1v2]ty āḍhyo mahādhano mahābhogo vistīrṇṇa,viśālaparigraho, vaiśravaṇadhanapratispardhī, tena sadṛśāt kulāt kalatramānītaṃ, sa tayā sārddhaṃ, krīḍati ramate, paricārayati
msItem.explicit: [259r13] dhyānastimitagambhīre prajñāpadmaprabodhake || tasmin bodhimahātīrthe sthitvā bodhipurātsukaḥ prakṣārayeccheṣapāpaṃ tuṣite sau [259r14] yayau mudā || tatrastho yā ciraṃ rete dṛṣṭvā lokaṃ kṛpānvitaḥ || tat kim idam upanītam evaṃ hi || mātaryapakāriṇaḥ prāṇinaḥ | ihaiva vyasanaprayāta[259r15]yātārāvalaṃbino bhavantīti || satatasamupajāyamānapremaprasādāvat_ mānamānasaiḥ satpuruṣair mātaraḥ śuśrūṣaṇīyā iti

supportDesc.foliation: Nepālākṣarā numerals, bottom right margin, verso (under running marginal invocation).
Arabic numerals, top right margin, verso.

layout.p: 15 lines per page, approximately 55-60 akṣaras per line.

item.marginalia: Running invocation (guru), bottom right margin, verso.

bindingDesc.p: Leather cover with title, classmark and decorations in golden letters on the spine; two flyleaves of European paper both at the beginning and the end; 19th-century library binding (probably bound by Wiseman as many other manuscripts acquired in 1873-6).

origin.origDate: 1873 CE ("'written 1873. [...] Copied to order for the University Library, through Dr D. Wright, from the only early copy known to exist, still preserved at Kāṭmāṇḍū"; Bendall 1883: 1).

history.provenance: Bought by Wright, Daniel Dr. D. Wright in 1873.

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card for admissions procedures contact Cambridge University Library Admissions).
